text: Modifies floating point attribute values on the incoming geometry.
The Attribute Adjust Float SOP provides an interface to vary

type attribute values, reducing the need to create VOP networks or write VEX code. It allows modification by a uniform value or a varying value for each element. The varying values can be generated fully randomly or sampled from a spatially-coherent noise pattern.

This node can also post-process the values, for example by blending them with another attribute or limiting them to the specified range. Additionally, it has the functionality to convert between units of frame and time or between degrees and radians.
The following graph provides a basic schematic view of the processes behind Attribute Adjust Float.
The subset of the input geometry to apply the modifications to. Leave this blank to affect all elements.

The name of the attribute to create or modify. If the attribute does not exist with the given name, it will be added to the selected
. As this node can be used on

type attributes, if you just give it the vector attribute itself, it will adjust the vector’s length, which is a scalar quantity. But you can also use this node to adjust a single component of the vector, which is also a scalar. To identify which vector component, you can either use the square bracket indexing or dotted subscripts.

Generates a value that will be combined with the incoming attribute value. When this option is turned off, only post-processing will be done.
Specifies how to combine the generated adjustment value with the incoming attribute value. If the target attribute does not exist on the input geometry, all operations will have the same effect.
Use this operation if you want to ensure the attribute is created, but don’t want to overwrite any existing value. If the target attribute is already present, its values will be left untouched.
Use this operation if you want to overwrite any existing value with the generated adjustment value.
The generated adjustment value will be added to the existing attribute value.
The generated adjustment value will be subtracted from the existing attribute value.
The existing attribute value will be multiplied by the generated adjustment value.
Output will be minimum of the existing attribute value and the adjustment value.
Output will be maximum of the existing attribute value and the adjustment value.
Specifies how the adjustment value is generated.

will generate varying values across each element of the geometry, in which case varying values will be inside a well defined range or selected from a list of specific values. Additionally, you can provide another attribute to use as the adjustment value for every element.
The adjustment value will be the same for all elements in the geometry. Use this to do simple math operations for all elements. For example, to offset all element values.
The adjustment values will be sampled fully randomly. Adjustment values can be inside a well defined range or selected from a list of specific values.
The adjustment values will be sampled based on a coherent noise field using the
. Adjustment values can be inside a well defined range or selected from a list of specific values.
Value of the attribute specified in
will be used as the adjustment value.
The adjustment value will be generated in the selected range. This parameter governs how this range is specified. You can also provide a list of specific values or multiple ranges by selecting
, which can be useful to create attribute values representing specific trigger frames.
The range contains all values between

The adjustment value will be one of the discrete listed values. The probability of selecting each value is proportional to its
controls how the adjustment value is sampled for each element.
Sets the adjustment to this value for every element in the geometry.
Sets the minimum limit of the custom range.
Sets the maximum limit of the custom range.
This value lies in the center of the custom range.
Sets the length of the custom range; that is, the difference between the maximum and minimum of the range will be equal to the value of this parameter.
Provides a way to control distribution of the generated adjustment values.
Generated adjustment values will be uniformly distributed within the custom range.
The generated value will be fed through the
to produce the final adjustment value. You can use this option to shift the values or create gaps in the given range.
range using different pattern types, while shifting values towards the minimum limit of the range:
Allows for a percentage of elements to extend beyond the given range. Use the outlier visualizer button next to
to see which elements are selected as outliers. It is possible to extend the range beyond the minimum and/or maximum limits, either by adding or multiplying the selected limits with
, forcing 15% of the points to live up to 2 seconds longer (in
Using outliers to extend both minimum and maximum range limit:
It is possible to achieve similar value manipulation by using
lets you to precisely control the proportion of points that fall outside the proper range.
The intermediate uniformly-distributed value will be fed through this ramp to obtain the adjustment value. Vertical axis of this ramp spans the custom range.
Controls the number of outliers. Value of
means that the adjustment value for 15% of all elements will fall outside the original range.
Integer attribute to store whether an element is outlier (indicated by
Controls how much the outlier range extends beyond the original. You can extend the maximum range, minimum range, or both either by multiplication or addition.
will be added to the maximum and/or minimum of the original range.
will multiply the maximum and/or minimum of the original range.
Only extend the minimum limit of the range.
Extend both the minimum and maximum limit of the range.
Controls random selection of outliers. Change the value of the
if the outlier selection is undesirable.

To create a float type attribute
with values rounded to integer values, turn on this checkbox and set the
Controls the spacing between the generated adjustment values.
Controls the number of sets of possible adjustment values. Each set can be a single value or a list of numbers. Probability of selecting each adjustment from each set is proportional to its
mode, the set will only contain the
Samples the given adjustment value with the specified weight. Values with lower
will be selected less frequently. When all weights are the same, each adjustment value has the same probability.
Sets adjustment values by a list of independent range sequences or numbers. The listings can be separated by whitespace, commas and semi-colons. Use the syntax
is not provided, the default value of
Each expanded values will be assigned the same
Specifies the attribute storing the adjustment value to use. The attribute value can be pre-scaled (
) before it is combined with the incoming attribute value.
Scales the adjustment value before it is combined with the incoming attribute value.
Offsets the adjustment value before it is combined with the incoming attribute value.
Specifies how the pseudo-random number generator is seeded for each element to produce the adjustment value.
will use the point, primitive, or vertex number depending on
. Topology changes on the input geometry can shift element numbers, causing different adjustment values to be used.
lets you provide an integer attribute to make sure the random value is not dependent on element order.
In case of a particle simulation, use
attribute to apply the same random value to the particles throughout their lifetime. You can also use
to apply the same random value to multiple elements.
The attribute to use for seeding random number generation.
All generated values depend randomly on this value. Choose a different value if the current seed produces undesirable samples.
The type of noise to generate. Different algorithms give noise with different characteristics.
The default. A faster and more interesting variant of Perlin noise.
Sparse Convolution noise is similar to Worley noise. Does not have artifacts at grid points.
Produces a bumpy output. Named for its alleged resemblance to alligator skin.
A noise where the visual details are the same size.
A noise that’s stable over time, like a rotated Perlin noise, useful to create noise that seems to swirl and flow smoothly across time. Use the
parameter below to control the rotation.
A noise similar to Perlin but the noise lattice is on a tetrahedral mesh rather than a grid.  This can avoid the grid patterns often visible in Perlin noise.
Produces cellular features similar to plant cells, ocean waves, honeycombs, cratered landscapes, and so on.
A variant of Worley noise that produces blunted and cornered features.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Manhattan distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
A variant of Worley F2-F1 noise that uses Chebyshev distance calculation. Useful when you want unusual-looking noise.
The node generates values for each element by sampling a noise field at the location specified by this vector attribute on the incoming geometry. If this is
(point position, the default), the points of the geometry will appear to swim through the noise. If you want the noise to
to the points, you can copy the initial point positions into a
attribute and use that attribute here instead.
Uniform scale of elements in the noise.
Per Component button for separate scales along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you scale the
Offset within the evaluated noise field (added to each axis). If you have the general noise effect you want, but want to get a different set of values for a different look, try changing the offset.
You can animate the noise using an expression such as
here. This is faster to compute than

across the noise field, which may or may not be acceptable.
Per Component button for separate additional offsets along each axis.
Per Component button, this lets you add the a separate offset along each axis.
Turn this checkbox on to use a VEXpression to override parameters based on arbitrary attribute values.
Vary the generated noise with time. Some noise types do not support this feature.
Applying animation this way on geometries with millions of element count is slower to compute than using expressions such as
is on, this controls the rate of change of the noise pattern.
The fractal controls let you add additional fractal noise on top of the output of the basic noise type.
Does not add any additional noise on top of the basic noise.
Adds pseudo-random noise on top of the basic output.
but dampens the noise in the valleys, which can be useful for generating mountainous terrain.
Like terrain, but with more sharpness in the valleys.
The following parameters are available when Fractal type is anything except
The number of iterations of distortion to add to the output of the basic noise. The more iterations you add, the more

the output. Note that the output may have fewer octaves than this parameter (that is, increasing the parameter will eventually stop adding detail), because the node eventually stops when there’s no more room to add more detail in the output.
The frequency increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. Note that you can use a negative value.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise added to the basic output. The higher the value the larger the
added to the output. You can use a negative value for roughness.
to the basic noises by warping the noise space.
Controls base feature size of the generated noise. The value applies to each axis.
Widens the peaks or valleys of the noise output.
Accumulates the warp for each iteration (octave) of added fractal noise. This can add interesting smudgy effects when used in images, and interesting landmarks when used for terrain.
Accumulates the warp for each iteration (octave) of added fractal noise.

. Because this parameter is fractional, you can’t just use
to animate it, since all integral values will look the same, representing a complete revolution. Instead, try something like
Displays a set of controls to further fine tune the output attribute value. All post-process modifications will take place after adjustment is applied to the attribute, unless set otherwise.

If this checkbox is turned on, it overwrites the default value property for the target attribute. Merging the output of this node with another geometry that is missing the attribute guarantees that new values will be initialized to this

title: Attribute Adjust Float
summary: Modifies floating point attribute values on the incoming geometry.
